text: The WACA Ground during a Test match between Australia and England in December 2010. The WACA Ground is a sport ground in Perth, Western Australia. The ground was established in 1893 and operated by the Western Australian Cricket Association. It hosted its first Test match in 1970 when Australia played England. The first One Day International (ODI) on the ground was played in 1980 and its first Twenty20 International (T20I) was played in 2007.W.A.C.A. Ground, CricInfo. Retrieved 2020-02-21. Women's Test cricket was first played on the ground in 1958, the first women's on the ground ODI was played in 2005 and the first women's T20I on the ground was played in 2020.Western Australia Cricket Association Ground, Perth, CricketArchive. Retrieved 2020-02-21. The last Test match was played on the ground in 2017 with major international matches moving to the modern Perth Stadium.Fordyce T (2017) Ashes: Farewell to the Waca, English cricket’s graveyard, BBC Sport, 2017-12-11. Retrieved 2020-02-21.Martin A (2017) Farewell to the ramshackle Waca, often a graveyard of English Ashes hopes, The Guardian, 2017-12-10. Retrieved 2020-02-21.Thomas C (2020) Perth's WACA Ground is no place for Test cricket in 2020, as laptops melt and spectators sizzle, ABC News (Australia), 2020-01-20. Retrieved 2020-02-21. The ground continues to be used by Western Australia and for women's international matches, hosting five matches in the 2020 ICC Women's T20 World Cup.T20 World Cups Coming To Perth, Western Australian Cricket Association, 2019-07-22. Retrieved 2020-02-22. In cricket, a five-wicket haul (also known as a "five-for" or "fifer") refers to a bowler taking five or more wickets in a single innings. This is regarded as a notable achievement.Pervez MA (2001) A Dictionary of Cricket, p.31. Hyderabad: Sangam Books (India). This article details the five-wicket hauls taken on the ground in official international Test and One Day International matches. Ellyse Perry took the only five-wicket haul in women's Test matches on the ground in 2014. The first bowler to take a five-wicket haul in a Test match on the WACA Ground was Australian Jeff Thomson, who took five wickets at a cost of 93 runs (5/93) in 1974 against England in the second Test played on the ground.Walters caps the routSecond Test Match, MCC in Australia and New Zealand, 1974–75, Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, 1976. Retrieved 2020-02-22.Bagchi R (2013) 20 great Ashes moments No9: Lillee and Thommo savage England, 1974, The Guardian, 2013-05-28. Retrieved 2020-02-22.Williamson M (2014) Shell-shocked and bloodied, CricInfo, 2014-10-11. Retrieved 2020-02-22. The best innings bowling figures in Test matches were achieved by Glenn McGrath who took 8/24 for Australia against Pakistan in 2004.English P (2004) Eight for McGrath the Great, CricInfo, 2004-12-19. Retrieved 2020-02-22. The only woman to take a five-wicket haul on the ground is Australia's Ellyse Perry who took 5/28 in a Test match in 2014.Nicholson R (2014) Cross rocks Australia after Edwards rally, CricInfo, 2014-01-12. Retrieved 2020-02-22. The first five-wicket haul in an ODI on the ground was taken by New Zealander Richard Hadlee who took 5/32 against India in the first ODI played on the ground in 1980.New Zealand v India 1980–81, World Series Cup, Wisden Crcketers' Almanack, 1982. Retrieved 2020-02-22. ==Key== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Symbol !
